text: 1. Let the women who are with child move away 1 !

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 2. Verily, from the beginning he (the self) is in man as a germ, which is called seed.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 3. This (seed), which is strength gathered from all the limbs of the body, he (the man) bears as self in his self (body). When he commits the seed to the woman, then he (the father) causes it to be born. That is his first birth. (1)

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 4. That seed becomes the self of the woman, as

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: if one of her own limbs. Therefore it does not injure her.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 5. She nourishes his (her husband's) self (the son) within her. (2) She who nourishes, is to be nourished.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 6. The woman bears the germ. He (the father) elevates the child even before the birth, and immediately after 1 .

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 7. When he thus elevates the child both before and after his birth, he really elevates his own self,

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 8. For the continuation of these worlds (men). For thus are these worlds continued.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 9. This is his second birth. (3)

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 10. He (the son), being his self, is then placed in his stead for (the performance of) all good works.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 11. But his other self (the father), having done all he has to do, and having reached the full measure of his life, departs.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 12. And departing from hence he is born again. That is his third birth.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 13. And this has been declared by a Ri shi (Rv. IV, 27, 1): (4)

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 14. 'While dwelling in the womb, I discovered all the births of these Devas. A hundred iron strongholds kept me, but I escaped quickly down like a falcon.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 15. Vâmadeva, lying in the womb, has thus declared this. (5)

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: And having this knowledge he stepped forth, after this dissolution of the body, and having obtained all his desires in that heavenly world, became immortal, yea, he became immortal. (6)

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 243:1 Some MSS. begin this adhyâya with the sentence apakrâmantu garbhi n ya h , may the women who are with child walk away! It is counted as a paragraph.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 244:1 By nourishing the mother, and by performing certain ceremonies both before and after the birth of a child.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
